subjective: The patient, Charles, reports experiencing distressing symptoms, primarily shortness of breath which occurs more often than he is accustomed to. He adds that his eyes frequently water, sometimes associated with the breathlessness. Charles shared that he has gone to urgent care in the past due to these symptoms and was given a nebulizer and prescribed an inhaler which he uses when the need arises. However, he has not reported any rashes, nausea, vomiting, or swelling of the lips and throat. He is unsure of when exactly the symptoms may come on, as he has experienced them in various situations  at home, when his cat is not around, and while outside.
objective: The doctor's physical examination revealed no signs of distress or allergic reactions like an angioedema or audible stridor. A faint expiratory wheezing in all lung fields was detected when the patient's lungs were listened to. The patient's vital signs were good; his pulse and pulse ox were normal. There were no symptoms at the time of examination. The results of his chest xray and pulmonary function test were also normal.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor diagnosed Charles with allergic asthma. To manage this, the doctor instructed him to continue the use of his albuterol inhaler, start taking Singulair 10mg daily, and agreed to initiate allergy testing, starting with skin testing. The doctor mentioned the possibility of further testing and potential immunotherapy. The doctor intends to see Charles the following week to schedule the skin testing. The doctor also guide the patient to bring his cat for the next appointment as it could potentially be a trigger.

subjective: Patient, Bryan, reported that he started experiencing back pain and a sensation of pins and needles in his right foot a few hours after raking leaves in his yard. He had previously experienced similar back pain around three years ago. He stated that a hot shower and sitting provided some relief, but bending over caused some pain. He also denied being very physically active in general. His partner, who accompanied him, reported that Bryan experienced increased pain upon standing up. His partner also highlighted that Bryan has a high pain tolerance and would only voice his discomfort if it were significant.
objective: Upon medical examination by the doctor, the patient showed pain upon flexion and some pain upon palpation around the L5 area. His dorsiflexion was normal and pulses were equal in all extremities. The patient also reported some tingling sensation in his right leg. An Xray review showed no abnormalities.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed the patient's condition to most likely be a sprain in the lower back. The treatment plan included rest, a prescription of meloxicam, and some physical therapy sessions to aid in his recovery. Should the problem persist, the doctor asked him to get back in touch for possibly conducting an MRI. The patient's partner requested an immediate MRI, but the doctor suggested waiting for a couple of weeks to gauge the effectiveness of the current treatment plan before conducting an MRI.

subjective: Patient Gregory presented with a nonhealing foot ulcer that hes had for approximately two months. It recently became red and started draining. There may be a history of minor trauma as he reported developing the ulcer after walking barefoot on the beach. He mentioned he had been prescribed some medication by his primary care physician, but had yet to pick it up. The patient also mentioned intermittent throbbing in the foot but no specific pain. His prime concern is the redness and drainage of his foot ulcer. Gregory reported that he has diabetes and noted his previous A1C reading was around 10 which is considered high.
objective: Upon physical examination of the foot, a one by twoinch circular wound was visible on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot. Redness, edema, and drainage were present, though no necrosis, odor, or bony exposure was detected. The patient experienced increased pressure, but not distinct pain when the area was touched. There was no fever and an xray revealed no evidence of osteomyelitis, ruling out bone infection.
assessment_and_plan: The patient was diagnosed with a diabetic foot ulcer. s include ordering an AnkleBrachial Index (ABI) to evaluate blood supply in the foot, performing debridement to remove dead tissue, and prescribing the patient Clindamycin (400 mg) to be taken twice a day for seven days to address the infection. The patient was advised to pick up a surgical shoe to minimize pressure on the foot during healing. A followup appointment was scheduled for two weeks later, with instructions to call the office in case of worsening symptoms, or to seek urgent care if there are signs of progression such as fever or the ulcer changing color.

subjective: The patient, Stephanie Morales, a 36yearold female, came in complaining of pain in her left ankle resulting from a slipandfall incident on ice two days prior to the visit. The pain is localized to the outside of the ankle, which is also swollen. She has attempted to manage the pain and swelling with ibuprofen, ice, and elevation, with minimal success. Stephanie has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure, for which she has been maintaining a diet and taking her medications respectively. Her blood sugar levels have been stable and she regularly checks them. She is due for an ophthalmologist appointment for a diabetic eye exam. She needs a refill for her blood pressure medication, Norvasc.
objective: Upon physical examination, the doctor found tenderness over the patient's lateral malleolus and the fifth metatarsal of her left ankle. There was evidence of swelling and redness. Pain with valgus stressing of the ankle was noted. The examination of her neck, lungs, and heart appeared normal, with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur that was already known. The patient's blood pressure was 120/70.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed that the patient probably had an ankle sprain but recommended an Xray to rule out a fracture due to the tenderness present. The doctor provided a plan of treatment including an air splint and crutches for the ankle, alongside a prescription of naprosyn 500mg twice a day for pain control. The patient was also advised to avoid weightbearing, elevate the foot, and apply ice for symptom relief. Metformin should be continued for diabetes control, and the patient was reminded to keep her upcoming ophthalmologist appointment. The doctor also plans to order another hemoglobin A1C test for the patient's diabetes and refill her prescription for Norvasc for high blood pressure management.

subjective: The patient, Wayne, reported having a nonhealing sore on his right foot for approximately two to three weeks. He had not sustained any trauma other than tightfitting shoes that he no longer uses. The patient has been experiencing neuropathy and has no sensation at the wound site. The patient also mentioned that he has diabetes and his last Hemoglobin A1C was slightly over eight.
objective: The doctor performed a physical examination where Wayne's vital signs were observed as normal. His foot examination uncovered a one by twoinch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot. Characteristics of the wound included yellow slough, minimal granulation tissue, but no odor, erythema, cellulitis, necrosis, fluid collection, or bony exposure. Vascular exams showed palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses, with no palpable dp or pt pulses, but Doppler signs were present. Lastly, his right foot Xray was reviewed and showed no evidence of osteomyelitis.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor recommended ordering an ankle brachial index (ABI) to determine the blood supply to the foot, office debridement to remove dead tissue, and a prescription for collagenase ointment for daily use. The patient was also advised to wear a surgical shoe to alleviate pressure off the wound area. Revisit after two weeks was proposed with a possible referral to a vascular specialist if the ABI indicates suboptimal blood supply for wound healing. No antibiotics were deemed necessary. The doctor also suggested a consultation for better diabetes management to assist with wound healing considering the patient's slightly elevated Hemoglobin A1C.

subjective: The patient, William, reported that he injured his right knee while at a trampoline park a week ago. He experienced an immediate pain and heard a snap, with the outside of the knee hurting more. The patient has been taking Tylenol for the pain, which did not provide substantial relief. He also elevated the knee, but has not applied any ice or heat packs. The patient has hypertension, for which he was recommended to get a blood pressure cuff. Furthermore, he has diabetes and is currently on medication for both ailments.
objective: The doctor conducted a physical examination of the patient's heart and lungs, which revealed a slightly high blood pressure but no abnormities in relationship to his lungs and heart. The physical examination of the knee showed bruising and swelling on the lateral aspect of the knee, with no effusion. The patient was able to bend the knee partially, but had a limp and difficulty walking. An Xray of the knee showed no evidence of fractures or bony abnormality.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed a potential lateral ligament strain in the patient's right knee. She prescribed meloxicam for pain and swelling, and recommended physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the injured area. She also suggested to have additional imaging if the pain persists. The doctor decided to continue with the lisinopril prescription for the patient's hypertension but suggested that blood pressure levels need better management, potentially with medication adjustments. An echo was also ordered. As for diabetes, the doctor mentioned the need for the patient to regularly check their blood sugar levels. She also ordered an A1C test for a better understanding of long term blood glucose control and a lipid panel for potential medication adjustments.

subjective: The patient, Matthew, presented with longterm lower back pain, worsened by standing or sitting for extended periods, and improved by lying down. The pain started about a month ago, with radiating pain down his left leg described as an "electrical toothache," ranging from 6/10 to sometimes going beyond 10/10. The pain is located at a specific spot at his lower back where he previously had a suspected fracture from a fall, three decades prior. There is weakness in both legs.
objective: Upon examination, no bony abnormalities, redness, or bruising were identified. Matthew presented with pain to palpation at the L4 vertebrae, and pain with flexion and extension of his back. He exhibited 4/5 strength in the left leg, and 5/5 on the right, with brisk reflexes and intact motor and sensory functions in both lower extremities. MRI results disclosed a disk herniation at the L4L5 vertebrae level, further associated with nerve root impingement.
assessment_and_plan: Matthew has been diagnosed with acute disk herniation at the L4L5 vertebrae level with nerve root impingement causing lower back and radiating leg pain. Previous use of NSAIDs and physical therapy provided no relief. An epidural steroid injection has been recommended for antiinflammatory effect at the inflammation site. After the procedure, the patient has been advised to return to physical therapy to strengthen the back area. Followup consultation is scheduled for a month later, as the injection could take twothree weeks to provide complete relief. Matthew agreed to this treatment plan.

subjective: The patient, Jacqueline, is experiencing anxiety over recent blood work showing that she has Hepatitis C. She indicates she has had a history of IV drug use about fifteen years ago, has decreased alcohol intake to approximately one beer per day, currently smokes one to two cigarettes per day, and has been feeling fatigued at the end of the day. No other current medical conditions were reported. Family history includes hypertension, diabetes, and depression.
objective: The doctor performed a physical exam finding the patient in no distress with no jaundice on her skin. Her heart rate and rhythm are regular with a 2 out of 6 systolic murmur that is unchanged from the previous year. Examination of her lungs reveals no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Her abdomen is soft with present bowel sounds and no hepatosplenomegaly. There is no gait disturbance or edema. Lab results show that the Hepatitis C antibody test was positive and there is an elevated AST level of 39, though albumin, ALT, and total bilirubin were normal.
assessment_and_plan: Based on the physical examination and lab results, the patient has initial labs consistent with Hepatitis C. The doctor's plan is to validate the diagnosis with additional blood work, checking Hep C RNA and the HCV genotype. The doctor also plans to evaluate the severity of the liver disease by checking for fibrosis of the liver with a specialized ultrasound. Once these results are obtained, the treatment plan will be determined. The doctor has also advised the patient to have her family screened for Hepatitis C. The next appointment is scheduled in three weeks.

subjective: The patient has been struggling with headaches for years which usually coincided with her menstrual cycles and periods of stress. Recently, these headaches have been occurring more frequently and with increased severity, provoking concern. The headaches are typically located on the right side and also manifest as a severe pulsing sensation behind the eye. The patient has also been experiencing a ringing in her ears and intermittent blurred vision. She has noticed that her headaches worsen when she exercises, specifically when running.
objective: During the physical examination, her vital signs including blood pressure were normal. Heart exam indicated a normal sinus rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The funduscopic examination revealed papilledema  swelling behind the eye. A neurological exam showed intact cranial nerves one through twelve and normal reflexes. The musculoskeletal exam identified a normal gait.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor is concerned that the patient has idiopathic intracranial hypertension, where there is an increase of pressure in the brain without any known cause. The symptoms of headaches, worsening with activity, ringing in the ears, and changes in vision align with this. There is concern that if the pressure continues to increase, there might be permanent changes to the patient's vision. Further testing will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis. An MRI will be completed to identify any potential contributing conditions. A spinal tap will be performed to evaluate the pressure in the brain and potentially alleviate some of the patient's discomfort if there is indeed elevated pressure. The patient is also scheduled to be seen by a neuroophthalmologist for a complete eye exam. If the condition is confirmed, there are medications available to manage and prevent increases in intracranial pressure. The patient was also advised that weight loss and exercise will be an important part of the treatment. The team in the front office will work on getting preapproval from the patient's insurance company for the MRI.

subjective: The patient, Jack, experienced a car accident a week ago where his neck and head were jerked forward. After that accident, he's been experiencing neck pain whenever he moves head, rating it around a 7 on a severity scale. The pain is localized to the back of his neck and hasn't been improving. He has taken ibuprofen, which helped minimally. He can mostly move his head side to side but experiences pain when doing so and had a few headaches early on. There has been no swelling, bruising, hearing problems, or visual disturbances.
objective: Upon physical examination, the patient experienced pain upon palpation of the neck, flexion, extension, and rotation of the neck. No pain was experienced when the back or shoulders were pressed, and the patient was unable to touch his ear to his shoulders due to pain. Xray results showed no signs of fracture or bony abnormalities.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed that the patient may have a neck strain, commonly referred to as whiplash. The patient is to be put on a regimen of antiinflammatories (Motrin 600mg every 68 hours) and a muscle relaxant (Flexeril 10mg every 12 hours as needed). He is advised to rest his neck and avoid straining it. The doctor has also ordered an MRI to rule out a concussion or any other potential complications from the accident. Once the MRI results are in, the patient will be referred to physical rehab or a chiropractor.

subjective: The patient, Bobby, presented with pain in his right shoulder which has been going on for a few weeks. The pain initiated after he was involved in some physically demanding work in his backyard and was severe enough to bother him during movement and at night, especially when he slept on the side of his pain. Bobby had some history of damage to that shoulder from his youth. He selftreated with Advil and ice to dull the pain slightly. He does not have any numbness but has felt soreness in both his feet and ankle joints due to his physical activity. His wife suggests he may be dehydrated.
objective: Upon examination, Bobby was found to have a good overall health condition. Physically, Bobby has unrestricted movement of his arm but experienced some pain during movement, especially on the outer side of the right shoulder. The doctor noted a minor limitation in the active and passive range of motion and tenderness at the humerus' greater tuberosity. Neurovascular examination found a good hand grip, a capillary refill of less than 3 seconds, and intact sensation. An xray indicated no fractures.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed that Bobby likely has tendinopathy in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder. He suggests ordering an MRI for appropriate diagnosis and recommends referring Bobby to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks for treatment. If the symptoms persist, the patient can consider steroid injections for relief. For his foot and ankle stiffness, the doctor suggests epsom salt soaks for relief. If there are no improvements, further investigation will be done.

subjective: Mr. Jackson, a 45 years old male with a history of Diabetes TypeII and mild intermittent asthma came to the hospital complaining of right elbow pain for the past three weeks. He shared that the pain started around the same time he began playing tennis frequently. The elbow pain intensifies with movements, and he scores it as an eight on a scale of zero to ten when using his elbow and three when at rest. The pain is located on the outside part of the elbow. It is sharp, stabbing, and shooting. Pain relief medications like Tylenol and Ibuprofen provide short term relief, and icing the elbow doesn't seem to be effective. He denied any recent injuries or trauma. He also stated that his asthma is under control but his blood sugar levels have been around 150160.
objective: Physical exam revealed a moderate grade three out of six systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from prior exams. Mr. Jackson was found to have moderate lateral epicondylar tenderness of the right elbow and moderate pain with passive range of motion of the right elbow. However, there was no palpable joint effusion and only mild pain was noted with resisted extension of the right wrist. An Xray of the right elbow showed no acute fracture or other bony abnormality, malalignment or joint effusion.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor diagnosed Mr. Jackson with Acute Lateral Epicondylitis, also known as Tennis Elbow. This was likely a result of increased tennis activity. Despite being on Metformin twice daily, Mr. Jacksons blood sugars were a bit off probably due to his dietary habits. His asthma was under good control. The doctor recommended that Mr. Jackson rest his arm and avoid playing tennis or any repetitive stress on the right arm for four to six weeks. He was advised to ice the elbow for twenty minutes at least three times per day. He was to be given a brace for the right forearm to help with the discomfort and was also prescribed Ultram 50mg/day for pain relief. A followup in four weeks was arranged. The doctor increased Mr. Jacksons Metformin dosage to 1000mg twice per day and asked him to check his blood sugar levels twice daily for the next two weeks, and share the readings. A Hemoglobin A1C level, CBC and Chem12 blood tests were ordered. His existing asthma medications were continued and a refill of Albuterol was prescribed.

subjective: The patient, Angela, has a history of kidney stones, hypertension, and diabetes. She was recently treated for a kidney stone incident and is feeling better with no more pain or blood in the urine. She confirms having taken prescribed pain medication (Percocet) during her kidney stone incident. Angela also takes Norvasc for her hypertension and despite high readings at the doctor's office, she reports normal blood pressure readings at home. She's trying to manage her diet but finds it hard to avoid fast food due to her busy schedule. Angela confirms she is taking the prescribed 500 milligrams of Metformin daily for diabetes, but does not frequently check her sugar levels. Angela also reported occasional insomnia, which she tries to manage using meditation apps.
objective: Angela has had around seven to eight incidences of kidney stones, and claims the recent one has passed three days ago. Her blood pressure reading in the office was 150/90. She is on 2.5mg of Norvasc for her hypertension and 500mg of Metformin for diabetes. Physical examination shows no tenderness in the abdomen or on the patient's back. The doctor notes clear lungs bilaterally, a grade two out of six systolic ejection murmur which is stable, and her last recorded A1C level was 6.7.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor's assessment includes recurrent kidney stones, hypertension, diabetes, and insomnia. The doctor's plan includes urinalysis and a urine culture to ensure all is well after her recent kidney stone issue, and a referral to urology due to her frequent kidney stone issues. Her hypertension will continue to be managed by Norvasc with no changes made currently. The doctor also recommends a nutritional consult to assist with dietary habits and its relationship with hypertension. Angela will continue her current dose of Metformin for diabetes, and the doctor has asked her to monitor her blood sugar level before every meal. For her insomnia, the doctor has suggested use of 10 mg of melatonin as needed and to practice proper sleep hygiene. Angela is to return for a followup in three months.

subjective: The patient reports suffering from chronic asthma symptoms, including coughing and wheezing. She experiences these symptoms almost every day, with flareups occurring approximately once a month or every other month for the past six months. These episodes often lead to urgent care visits where she receives treatment with either antibiotics or steroids and has even resulted in an emergency room visit. Triggers for asthma flareups include getting sick with a cold and exposure to cats. The patient uses her blue inhaler, possibly Ventolin, every day and on waking up at night due to symptoms. The patient denies any tobacco, marijuana or ecigarette use. She enjoys outdoor activities like hiking, yet has to be mindful of her symptoms. The patient has been hospitalized for her asthma once, as a child.
objective: The patients vitals reveal a blood pressure of 128 over 82, a respiratory rate of 16, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Listening to the heart, the doctor found a regular rate and rhythm, no ectopic beats, rubs, murmurs, or gallops. However, lung sounds are diminished throughout with occasional slight expiratory wheezing, bilaterally. Neck exam is normal with no lymphadenopathy or carotid bruit. Her hands show strong bilateral pulses, no clubbing, and brisk capillary refill. Pulmonary function test results are consistent with an asthma diagnosis.
assessment_and_plan: The patient's symptoms indicate a condition of moderate intermittent asthma. The doctor plans to start the patient on Flovent 110 micrograms, one puff twice a day. Albuterol inhaler can be used two puffs every four to six hours as needed. Additionally, an asthma action plan will be arranged to better manage her symptoms. The patient will have a followup appointment in 30 days or sooner if symptoms worsen.

subjective: The patient, Larry, has been experiencing chronic back pain for a couple of years, which his primary care doctor referred him to address. He describes the pain as a sharp stabbing sensation that sometimes radiates down his right leg to his toe. Larry also suffers from some numbness and tingling, especially down his right leg to his foot. The pain seems to be exacerbated when he sits, and it has affected his ability to remain active and subsequently his weight. He has previously tried physical therapy and prescription pain medications but found no lasting relief. Surgery has been discussed but Larry is not inclined towards it. He was a smoker but quit about twenty years ago.
objective: During the physical exam, the doctor noticed midline tenderness at the L4 L5 disk space with rightsided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain was observed during lumbar flexion and positive on a supine straight leg test. There was decreased sensation to light touch on the right lateral thigh at the L4 dermatome, but patellar and Achilles reflexes were symmetrical. MRI results showed disk herniation with nerve impingement.
assessment_and_plan: The patients symptoms and MRI results are consistent with an L4 L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy. The doctor proposed a treatment plan involving a spinal injection with a corticosteroid under fluoroscopy to the exact area of pain. This would help decrease the inflammation that is causing the pain. The frequency of the injections would be based on the patient's response, not exceeding four times a year. The treatment plan was agreed upon, and an appointment for the first injection was set.

subjective: The patient, Kenneth, reported to have been experiencing pain in his right knee five days prior to the consultation. The pain occurred after a water skiing incident, where he made a jump and landed in a twisted position. He expressed that the knee was fine prior to the incident. The patient stated that he did not hear or feel a pop during the incident, but rather felt like something stretched. The knee swelled afterwards. He managed to get out of the water by himself, though the knee was sore and it is painful when he squats or bends. He also reported that he has been taking Lisinopril 20 milligrams for his high blood pressure and he checks it regularly at home; the record has been stable at 125/80. He also confirmed he is taking overthecounter Aleve twice a day and a cold pack to manage the knee pain.
objective: The doctor's physical examination revealed ecchymosis and edema on the right knee, with effusion and pain noticeable upon palpation of the right medial knee. Further exam showed decreased range of motion, negative varus and valgus test and negative Lachman sign. Exam also showed the blood pressure of the patient was 120/77 and his heart was maintaining a steady rate and rhythm, with clear lungs upon auscultation.
assessment_and_plan: Based on the physical examination and the subjective reporting of the patient, the doctor confirmed that the patient's right knee injury is likely a medial collateral ligament strain. Additionally, the patient's hypertension is wellmanaged on his prescribed medication. The doctor proposed to order an xray of the injured knee to verify the initial diagnosis and rule out any broken bones. If the xray result is as expected, the plan is to refer the patient to physical therapy and prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg once a day to reduce the swelling and pain. For the patient's hypertension, the doctor decided to keep the current Lisinopril 20 mg treatment and ordered a lipid panel for further assessment. As the patient is due for a tetanus shot, the doctor decided to provide that as a maintenance. The patient is also advised to avoid any strenuous activities, such as water skiing, until the result of the xray is out.

subjective: The patient, Kyle, visited his PCP after suffering from a cough for about three months. The coughing started after a strenuous day of lifting hay bales for his horses, and then he acquired a cold. His cough has since resolved. His PCP discovered a lung nodule during a chest Xray, which was later confirmed by a CAT scan. Kyle was referred to the current doctor because of this finding. Aside from his cough, Kyle maintains an active lifestyle, which includes frequent biking. Kyle has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, mostly affecting his hands, but it is currently managed with 7.5 mg of methotrexate weekly. He has quit smoking seven years ago, after a history of tobacco use. He denies any familial history of lung cancer but his mother had breast cancer. He denies any history of lung infections or pneumonia.
objective: The doctor carried out a physical examination. Kyle's vital signs are good, with a blood pressure of 124/76, heart rate of 70, respiration rate of 16, O2 sat on room air at 98%, and no fever. His lungs were clear and equal bilaterally, and his heart exhibited a regular rate and rhythm without any extra beats or abnormal sounds. Kyles skin was described as pink, warm, and dry, with no edema in the lower extremities. There was minor swelling in the knuckles of his third digit on each hand indicative of his rheumatoid arthritis. His pulses and capillary refill were within normal limits. A review of his chest CT scan revealed a solitary 2centimeter nodule in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe, and no evidence of any emphysematous disease.
assessment_and_plan: Kyle has an incidentally found right upper lobe lung nodule which the doctor plans to have removed via videoassisted thoracostomy. Presurgery, a PET CT will be scheduled to check if the nodule is metabolically active and Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT) will be carried out to assess baseline lung function. Postsurgery, Kyle will have a chest tube in and will be monitored for one day in the hospital. His rheumatoid arthritis appears to be under control, and he is advised to continue to follow up with his rheumatologist and comply with his current medication regimen with methotrexate. Despite the potential for the lung nodule to be benign, its removal is recommended due to Kyle's history of smoking.

subjective: The patient, Tyler, a 56yearold male with a past medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure, reported experiencing difficulty swallowing, particularly with solid foods, for the past 45 weeks. He described a feeling as if something is always stuck in his throat which can be painful and bothers him throughout the day. He denied any incident of full choking but expressed worry about potentially choking in the future. He did not note any complimentary symptoms such as coughing, blood in stools, vomiting, weight loss, chest pain, or shortness of breath. Regarding his diabetes, user claimed he is taking his prescribed medication (Metformin 500 mg twice daily), adhering to a better diet and exercise regimen and commonly checks his blood sugar which is within target range. His blood pressure at home was also mostly within normal range.
objective: Upon physical exam, the doctor noted no abnormalities in the patient's neck, thyroid, lymph nodes, throat, lung, heart, back and extremity. No masses, swelling, or redness was observed in these areas. The doctor detected some epigastric tenderness. The patient's blood pressure was measured in the office as 120/50.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor's primary concern was a possible narrowing of the patient's throat that might be causing the reported difficulty in swallowing. This may be resulting from a stricture or narrowing of the esophagus. The patient's diabetes seemed under control, based on his own reports and his blood pressure reading was within a normal range. The doctor planned to refer the patient to a gastroenterologist for further investigation of his swallowing issue and recommend initiation of Prilosec 20 mg once daily for possible reflux. The patient was also advised to chew food properly, especially hard foods like steak or meat. For the diabetes, the doctor planned to order a repeat of hemoglobin A1c test, additional blood tests to check for kidney function and refer the patient to ophthalmology for an eye exam related to his diabetes. The metformin regimen would continue, with a followup in a month to check results of the blood tests. For blood pressure management, the patient was asked to continue with Norvasc and contact the doctor if any issues arose. The doctor also noted to refill the patient's prescription for Norvasc.

subjective: The patient, a 45yearold male named Jerry, reported injuring his ankle while playing basketball with his son. He noticed it was bruised and swollen, particularly on the outside, and expressed discomfort while walking due to feelings of instability. Jerry expressed concern about the injury disrupting his gym workout routine and his upcoming commitment as a volunteer basketball coach starting in April.
objective: On physical examination, the doctor found exquisite tenderness on the lateral side of the ankle and some tenderness over the medial deltoid region. No skin rupturing was observed. The doctor also noted a brisk capillary refill and no severe malalignment. Upon viewing the Xray, the doctor diagnosed a displaced lateral malleolar fracture at the Weber C level.
assessment_and_plan: The patient has a lateral malleolar fracture which is causing instability while walking. Due to the location of the fracture, surgical intervention is recommended, involving the placement of plates and screws. This procedure will likely result in Jerry being nonambulatory for approximately three months, leading to the provision of crutches for mobility and the recommendation of coaching duties from the sidelines. In addition, the doctor prescribed meloxicam to help decrease the swelling, and advised regular icing and elevation of the ankle. Jerry mentioned he can do this as he works from home. Lastly, further support and followup will be provided to help manage the patients case and ensure a comprehensive treatment plan.

subjective: The 54yearold male patient, Mr. Edwards, presents with severe, stabbing facial pain focused on the right side of the face. He describes the pain as sometimes feeling excessively hot. He has been experiencing the pain for approximately two to three months and it comes in episodes that can last from few minutes to an hour. Specific triggers include certain temperatures and wind, and overthecounter pain relief medication like ibuprofen and Motrin has been ineffective. The patient says he does not have any numbness or tingling, and maintains face symmetry when showing teeth and performing facial movements. His vision is unaffected. He has a history of occasional headaches but does not suffer from migraines, adverse diseases like multiple sclerosis or brain tumors. His past treatments include selfcare like applying tiger balm and general pain killers but they haven't been effective. He has been referred to the neurosurgeon by his family doctor.
objective: Upon examination, the physician notes that the patient's facial movements are symmetric and his auditory ability is fine. However, the patient reported feeling numb on his right side when the doctor used cotton tape and distinguished dull feeling on his cheekbone area. By reviewing the patient's MRI, the doctor found that a small blood vessel is potentially pinching the trigeminal nerve.
assessment_and_plan: Based on the patients symptoms, examination results and the MRI findings, the doctor believes that Mr. Edwards is suffering from trigeminal neuralgia. Treatment will start with prescription medications like Tegretol aiming to reduce the excitability of the nerve and providing potential pain relief. Genetic testing might also be necessary considering Tegretol's potential sideeffects. The doctor plans to see how the patient reacts to this medication. If the medication is ineffective, surgical options may be explored to treat the nerve's compression by the blood vessel. The physician has proposed a followup in one month to check the effectiveness of the drugs.

subjective: Michelle, a physically active patient with no history of serious illnesses, reported an injury to her right knee which occurred while skiing in Vermont. She stated that her knee 'popped' upon falling and has been painful ever since. She described difficulty in bearing weight on it, with an associated feeling of instability or potential buckling. She also mentioned that she was able to bend the knee immediately after the incident, but not so much at present with similar issues regarding the straightening of the knee. The pain is concentrated on the outer part of the knee, with no reported numbing or tingling in her toes.
objective: A physical examination of the right knee showed edema and an effusion over the area. Michelle experienced pain upon palpation of the right lateral knee and displayed decreased flexion and extension. A positive Lachman sign was noted. Pulses in the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial were palpable, with no leg edema noted in the ankle. The previous Xray done did not show any bony abnormality in her right knee.
assessment_and_plan:
The doctor suspected that Michelle might have a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), a major ligament that aids the movement of the knee. s 
The doctor proposed ordering an MRI to confirm this diagnosis. In the meantime, Michelle was advised to continue her ibuprofen regimen for pain management. The doctor suggested she wear a knee brace for additional support and aimed to schedule the MRI within the next couple of days. After receiving the MRI results, they would discuss potential treatment options, including the choice of graft for a potential ACL repair.

subjective: The patient, Brandon, presented with severe neck pain, rating it as a 'twelve' on a scale where ten is extremely severe. He reported being involved in multiple car crashes, with the most recent one occurring in February of the current year. The patient has been to therapy and had surgery following previous accidents. Apart from the neck pain, the patient described experiencing headaches, occasional dizziness, numbness in the left arm and right leg, body spasms, and incapacity to work due to the severity of the pain. He reported sharp, incapacitating pain and stiffness that increases upon movement. He had previously been prescribed Fentanyl for his pain, which he hasn't received in several weeks.
objective: During the physical exam, the doctor found that the patient experiences severe pain upon palpation both on the bony process and on the muscles of the neck. His neck movement was moderately limited and caused him significant discomfort. The doctor did not observe any bruising, swelling, or lacerations at the time of the examination. The patient's Xray did not reveal any fractures.
assessment_and_plan:
The doctor initially diagnosed the patient with a neck sprain and decided to treat the patient conservatively. However, considering the patient's report that another healthcare worker suggested he might have a fracture, the physician decided to order a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scan to get a clearer image of the patient's neck.

(4) The doctor prescribed Robaxin (1500 mg to be taken every sixeight hours) as initial treatment for the patient's pain, recommending ice application and morning exercises to improve the situation. The doctor advised if the Robaxin does not help, they might consider using a heat pad or topical ointments like Biofreeze and possibly refer the patient for physical therapy. To explore further treatment options, the doctor suggested local injections could be considered, pending the results of the MRI. The doctor also provided the patient with a temporary work exemption due to his current physical condition.

subjective: Andrew, a 59yearold male, has a history of depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension. He recently experienced fatigue and shortness of breath during physical labor, which he attributes to a possible cold. Andrew is currently experiencing elbow pain and knee fatigue. Regarding his chronic conditions, Andrew has been managing his depression without medication by participating in barre classes. His sugar levels have been regularly monitored and stable, except for some diet slips during house parties. His blood pressure is also regularly monitored and under control.
objective: Andrew's vital signs in the office were normal, without fever. Physical exam showed scattered ronchi bilaterally on the lung exam, clearing with cough. There was some edema of the lower extremities, and pain upon palpation of the elbows bilaterally. Results of a chest xray were good with no airspace disease or pneumonia. Diabetic labs showed an elevated Hemoglobin A1c at eight.
assessment_and_plan:
For the upper respiratory infection, the assessment is a viral syndrome, possibly a cold. A Covid19 test will be ordered for confirmation. The plan includes rest and medication for symptomatic relief  Robitussin for the cough and Ibuprofen or Tylenol for fever. 

Depression is being managed successfully with nonpharmacological interventions such as barre classes. Further options for treatment (medication or psychotherapy) are deferred at this time.

His Type 2 Diabetes treatment plan includes an increased dosage of Metformin to 1000 milligrams, twice daily, and ordering of Hemoglobin A1c in four months time.

Andrew's high blood pressure is currently wellmanaged. The current treatment plan of Lisinopril 20 milligrams daily will be continued, along with an ordered lipid panel. Refill of Lisinopril will be provided. 

Followup scheduled in four months or if symptoms worsen.

subjective: Andrea, a 52yearold female with a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux came for her annual exam. She has been exercising and doing yoga, which has helped her arthritis, and she reports no recent joint pain. She stays on methotrexate once a week for arthritis and has no issues with it. Andrea still experiences palpitations, especially under stress and despite her physical activities to relieve it. Her last episode was a week ago. Her reflux symptoms have improved. The patient stopped drinking soda, and along with the protonix medication, she hasn't had a reflux flareup for over five months. She has nasal congestion due to allergies but reports no other symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, or vomiting.
objective: The physical exam showed a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, but her heart was in a regular rate and rhythm. Her lungs were clear. She has some right elbow edema, erythema, and pain upon palpation. There is no lower extremity edema. Event monitor results showed instances of atrial fibrillation, and the autoimmune panel shows that her rheumatoid arthritis is well controlled with methotrexate.
assessment_and_plan: The plan for the rheumatoid arthritis is to continue methotrexate 2.5 mg once a week, and the doctor offered to refer her back to the rheumatologist if needed. A prescription refill for methotrexate was made. For her atrial fibrillation, the plan is to keep her in a normal sinus rhythm by referring her to a cardiologist for a cardiac ablation. Lastly, for reflux, the plan is to continue protonix 40 mg daily, continue avoiding certain beverages and foods, and to monitor any new issues.

subjective: Albert, a 62yearold male with a medical history of depression, type 2 diabetes, and a kidney transplant, attended the followup visit due to an emergency room visit. He reported that he visited the emergency room because he didn't stay on top of his blood sugar readings and felt woozy over the weekend. Albert also mentioned that his eating habits were unhealthy in the last week due to his mother being in the hospital. Since his ER visit, he has been following his diet closely. Albert regularly takes his immunotherapy meds and his kidney function was reported as good from his last check with Dr. Reyes. Regarding his depression, Albert admitted that he had struggled a lot in past yearandahalf but meditation has been working well for him.
objective: During the physical examination, Albert did not show any signs of distress, however, the doctor noticed 1+ edema in his lower extremities. His vital signs were in the normal range but his blood sugar was 162, even though he didn't eat anything before the visit. Further laboratories showed an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.
assessment_and_plan: For Albert's hyperglycemia, the doctor planned to increase his Lantus to 20 units at night and monitor his blood sugar levels regularly. They also planned to order another hemoglobin A1c in a few months. Regarding the depression, the patient seemed to manage well with meditation, thus no medication or therapy was recommended. For his kidney transplant, everything seemed stable. He was advised to continue followups with Dr. Reyes for his immunosuppression medications.

subjective: The patient, Jerry, is a 54yearold male with a medical history significant for osteoporosis and multiple sclerosis. He has been experiencing insomnia, having tried various approaches including use of melatonin, meditation, and regular morning stretches, but without success. Jerry has been traveling a lot over the summer, which he describes as stressful. He saw his neurologist about six months ago and reports no issues with his medication for multiple sclerosis. Furthermore, Jerry mentions a lingering issue with his knee following surgery.
objective: During the physical examination, the doctor confirms clear lungs, normal heart sounds, good reflexes, and arthritic changes to the right knee. The patient's lower extremities show some weakness (4 out of 5 on the right side, and 3 out of 5 on the left side). The patient's vital signs in the office are reported to be within normal range. An xray image of Jerry's right knee shows signs of arthritis.
assessment_and_plan: For Jerry's osteoporosis, the doctor plans to continue with Fosamax and refills the prescription. The doctor advises Jerry to continue seeing his neurologist and to maintain his medication regimen for multiple sclerosis. As for the insomnia, the doctor does not offer a specific plan in this dialogue. The doctor also does not suggest a specific course of action for the arthritic changes in the right knee, identified through the xray image.

subjective: Mrs. Martinez, a 43yearold female, visited Dr. Gomez due to pain near her wrist in the region of the distal radius. The pain started when she missed a backhand stroke while playing tennis and hit the net pole which jarred her arm. She reported that a little swelling did occur, but there was no numbness in her hand although some pain was experienced on moving her wrist. She confirmed her medical history includes allergies, and she uses Flonase to manage them. She also had a past incident of getting wounded by a rake while doing lawn work.
objective: Dr. Gomez examined the patient's arm and did not find any fractures or abnormalities in the Xray. Upon pressing the affected part of her arm and flexing it, Mrs. Martinez affirmed some pain and tenderness, especially when her thumb was stressed.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed Mrs. Martinez's symptoms and physical assessment. He inferred that she likely had a strain and contusion to the distal radial muscle from the tennis incident. He ruled out any possibility of a fracture. Dr. Gomez prescribed conservative treatment at this point since a fracture was ruled out. He suggested the use of ice for any pain and swelling and an antiinflammatory drug, specifically, motrin (800 milligrams three times a day with food). The patient was advised to report back if there was no improvement after a week. The doctor then ordered the procedures and the medications as discussed.

subjective: The patient, Lawrence, a 62yearold male with a history of type I diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux, complains of shortness of breath, particularly after activities such as climbing stairs. He also experiences swelling, believes to be due to consumption of salty foods at social events. Lawrence has noticed the problems for about 10 days, and reports discomfort upon lying flat and feeling stiff in the mornings. He experienced an acute episode of breathlessness one night about a week ago. His diabetic condition is generally wellmanaged, closely monitoring his blood sugar levels except timetotime at weekends when he gets forgetful. Lawrence, a confessed chocolate lover, suggests that he is taking care of his health but sees room for improvement, especially with his propensity towards salty foods and chocolate bars. Regarding his depression, Lawrence seems to be struggling with it and it's been a tough one and a half year for him. He currently does not want to try medications and is open for suggestions regarding alternatives. He is currently on Omeprazole for reflux and is trying to limit his caffeine and Red Bull intake. His alcohol intake is reduced and he mentions that he does not want to harm himself or others.
objective: The doctor stated that his vital signs and oxygenation levels appeared normal at rest and were encouraging. The physical examination revealed no jugular venous distension or carotid bruits, a slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur on the heart exam, crackles at the bases of the lungs, and 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. The chest xray did not show any airspace disease, and laboratory results indicate no elevated white blood cell count or pneumonia.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor assessed Lawrence's shortness of breath as an acute episode of heart failure, probably due to fluid retention. The plan is to administer Lasix 40mg daily, monitor weight, and if any issues arise such as increased shortness of breath at rest, to either get in touch with the medical team or visit the emergency room. For his diabetes, a hemoglobin A1C test will be ordered for revisiting in a month and he was asked to consult his endocrinologist. His depression to be managed with psychiatric counseling and refrain from medications. Lastly, for his reflux, he was advised to continue with the Omeprazole 20mg daily.

subjective: Ms. James, a 42yearold female, reported pain in her right index finger after a skiing accident that took place five days ago. During this accident, she lost control and injured her finger, but she isn't sure on what. She rates her pain as a seven out of 10 and states that the ibuprofen she took seemed to have no effect on reducing her pain. She also mentions that she didn't ice it or use a splint. The patient also suffers from chronic constipation and takes Miralax, which she says is effective. She had her appendix removed when she was seven.
objective: The doctor examined the patient physically and through her recent Xray. The xray revealed a normal right hand with no fractures. On physical examination, however, the patient expressed pain when her finger was pushed, pulled, or squeezed over the joints.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor diagnosed Ms. James with a sprain of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP joint) in her right index finger. The plan for Ms. James includes fitting a splint on the affected finger and prescribing a strong antiinflammatory called Mobic (15 milligrams, once a day, for a twoweek period). The doctor asked the patient to return in two weeks for a followup to assess the healing process and determine the need for any hand therapy. The doctor gave the instruction to order the necessary medications and procedures as well.

subjective: The patient, Cheryl, is a 34yearold female with a medical history significant for hypertension. She presented with back pain that started six days prior to the consultation. Cheryl reported that the pain began while she was walking, describing it as if her back seized up on her. Along with regular walking sessions, she also mentioned that she had been doing deadlifts three times a week. The location of the pain was reported to be in the lower back and on both sides equally. She denied experiencing any numbness, tingling in her legs or feet, or weakness in her lower extremities. Aside from the back pain, Cheryl also mentioned enduring nasal congestion due to seasonal allergies. She disclosed that her blood pressure has been wellmanaged at home and she continues on her prescribed lisinopril.
objective: Upon examining Cheryl, her vital signs were stable and her blood pressure well controlled. A physical examination revealed pain to palpation on the right lateral aspect of her lumbar spine and pain with flexion and extension. Her straight leg raise test was negative. An Xray examination of her lumbar spine showed good boney alignment with no apparent fracture. Lab tests returned no signs of infection or elevated white blood cell count.
assessment_and_plan: Cheryl's back pain was diagnosed as a lumbar strain, possibly resulting from her physical activities. For her condition, the doctor prescribed meloxicam, 15 milligrams per day, and recommended alternating icing and heating the painful area. To help prevent further issues, Cheryl was referred to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. For her hypertension, Cheryl was advised to continue her lisinopril treatment, 10 milligrams daily, and monitor her blood pressure readings at home. Cheryl required a refill of her lisinopril which was ordered during the consultation.

subjective: Mrs. Anderson, a 44yearold female, complains of severe left shoulder pain for around a week, which began after she toppled over during a gymnastics class. She tried taking Tylenol to relieve the pain but found it unhelpful. She revealed a history of surgery on her left arm.
objective: Upon examination, any movement of the patient's left shoulder leads to pain. Xray findings showed no broken bones or fractures, suggesting that the joint might have been affected.
assessment_and_plan:
Mrs. Anderson possibly hurt her joint in the incident. The previous surgery on her left arm does not appear to be the cause of the present pain.

(4) The doctor recommended Mrs. Anderson to rest her arm and avoid lifting heavy weights with it for the next three to four weeks. She is advised to continue using overthecounter pain relievers, specifically taking 600mg of Ibuprofen three times a day for a week. If the pain persists, the use of an ice pack or heat pad may help. If the pain is still present after three weeks, she should return for another checkup. A further Xray may be needed based on how her situation develops. She is also recommended to try Advil or Aleve if needed. If the  pain increases she is permitted to call the doctor and may possibly arrange an earlier appointment.

subjective: Elizabeth is a 66yearold female with a past medical history significant for depression and hypertension. She reports being reasonably well and has been enjoying events and seeing her family, now that she has been vaccinated. Regarding her depression, Elizabeth says that weekly therapy sessions have been beneficial, particularly the inperson ones. She mentions having a supportive family around her. She is monitoring her blood pressure at home and reports that it is generally normal.
objective: During the physical examination, the doctor did not find any carotid bruits in Elizabeth's neck. There was a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at her heart, which was consistent with her past health records. Her lungs were clear, but there was some slight lower extremity edema bilaterally. Her blood pressure was good and her heart rate was normal indicating good management of her hypertension. An EKG was performed before the examination, and the result was normal.
assessment_and_plan: Elizabeth is managing her depression effectively through therapy without medication. As per her hypertension, her medication (lisinopril, 20mg per day) will continue and she will keep monitoring her blood pressure. If her pressures start rising, she needs to reach out to the doctor. For her annual examination maintenance, a mammogram has been scheduled.

subjective: Mr. Jose James, born 9/29/1957, has been experiencing persistent pain in his left shoulder and elbow for about five months, following a fall on icy stairs. The pain intensifies when he lifts weights, which has greatly affected his regular gym routine. He's stopped gym activities but continues to walk daily. Icing the area has provided minimal relief, and he denies any numbness or tingling.
objective: Upon examination, Mr. James exhibited tenderness in his left shoulder and elbow, without any erythema, deformity, or warmth. The HawkinsKennedy and Neer's tests were positive. The upper extremity strength was normal, and median radial ulnar sensation was intact along with abduction to 90°.
assessment_and_plan: The assessment indicates impingement syndrome of the left shoulder, possibly connected to the fall, which has also been causing the pain in the elbow. For now, the plan is to refer Mr. James to physical therapy at a frequency of two sessions per week  a regimen supervised by Dr. Martha Rivera. If this approach doesn't alleviate the pain, a cortisone injection could be contemplated. Mr. James has been instructed to continue icing the shoulder and advised to rest. He is to notify the medical team if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy.

subjective: The patient, Randy Gutierrez, is a baby who has been feeling unwell since the previous night. Symptoms include a runny, clear nose, a nonbarky cough, earpulling behaviors, rubbing of the nose, lowgrade fever (100.3°F), decreased appetite, bouts of irritability and difficulties in going to sleep despite seeming energetic. The baby has been exposed to his older sister and a nephew who have both been ill, the latter with a sinus infection. The child's parent has administered saline mist to the baby, as well as Tylenol when he was found to be sweating despite the AC being turned on, and baby Vick's was applied to his feet to assist with breathing. A humidifier has also been in use. The baby also has worsening cradle cap, for which a brush and regular Aveno shampoo are being used.
objective: Upon physical examination, the patient's ear condition is noted to be normal. The doctor suggests is a probable viral infection initiating the symptoms, possibly developing into a bacterial infection if untreated. This is deduced from his symptoms and exposure history from the sick sibling and nephew.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor deems it unnecessary to prescribe antibiotics at this point, suspecting a common viral infection. The baby's cradle cap condition is also evaluated, pointing out the cause to be essentially the same as dandruff. The plan is to monitor the baby's condition and only administer the prescribed medicine (same as his older sister's) if a barky cough develops. Continuous administration of fluids and rest is advised. Starting zarbee's cough syrup, with a dosage suited for babies under a year, for the regular cough is also recommended. The baby needs to avoid honey due to the risk of botulism but can have agave nectar. The usual shampoo for the baby is to be replaced with either head & shoulder's, Selsun blue, or Nizoral AD (regular strength) to treat cradle cap. This should be used two times per week, coupled with a soft brush and baby oil. The baby is scheduled for a followup appointment in a week.

subjective: The patient, Kayla Ward, is a 7thgrade girl who started presenting with facial acne around two years ago, which occurs most days. She claims to maintain a skincare regimen, which includes washing or wiping her face in the morning, and using an Elf facial cleanser, a toner, and PersaGel at night. These products have been somewhat useful, but the acne persists. There are no additional symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or pain. The acne does not seem related to her menstrual cycle. Her mother mentions that Kayla's skin condition worsened when she started school sports due to sweating.
objective: A full examination, except for under the underwear and bra, revealed multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities. Facial examination showed scattered skin colored papules, open and closed comedones, and erythematous papules mainly in the forehead area, and central cheeks and chin. The chest and back appear spared. The remainder of the exam was normal.
assessment_and_plan: The patient has mild to moderate acne, mostly comodonal with small inflammatory component. The advised treatment plan includes a daily morning routine of washing the face with a mild cleanser, followed by application of a noncomedogenic moisturizer with SPF 30 or higher. The evening routine should consist of washing the face with the same cleanser, then applying adapalene (0.1% cream) a few nights a week, gradually working up to everyday use. She can pair this with Persagel and a noncomedogenic moisturizer. Patient must also ensure to wear sunscreen when outside due to sensitivity from the atopic retinoid. The benign moles present on her were also noted and will be monitored. A follow up appointment will be scheduled in six months to assess the success of the treatment plan.

subjective: The patient, Julia Jones, a 25yearold female, presented for a consultation for breast reduction surgery. She has been considering the procedure for about six to seven years due to discomfort. Julia reported suffering from back and neck pain, which she attributed to her breasts. This pain has been a problem since high school. Specific symptoms she noted include bra strap indentations and occasional discomfort and numbness in her hands. Julia also mentioned that some physical activities, like running or jumping, are uncomfortable due to her breast size. The patient stated she does not take any pain medications for her discomfort but manages with a chiropractor's help. She shared that she has been taking propranolol for migraines. Julia mentioned she does not have children but plans to have them in the future. She expressed that she is not overly concerned about breastfeeding or potential scarring from a potential breast reduction. The patient's family history includes breast cancer, but she has not had a mammogram due to her age.
objective: Upon physical exam, Dr. Gonzalez noted asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis and indented shoulders from bra strap pressure. The patient does not have any nipple retraction or discharge, and no breast tenderness, masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy were noted during the exam. The doctor estimated a minimum resection volume of 1,792 grams based on Julia's body surface area.
assessment_and_plan: Julia has large, symptomatic macromastia and is a suitable candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty. The doctor explained the procedure details, the potential impact on future breastfeeding, potential changes to nipple sensation, and the potential for scar formation. Julia expressed willingness to proceed with the procedure once her anticipated insurance changes are confirmed. The doctor plans to wait until July to check with the insurance company for approval. Pending insurance approval, the plan is to schedule the procedure with a recommended initial recovery period in the hospital for close monitoring. Postsurgery, restrictions will include no heavy lifting and no driving for two to three weeks, with drains expected to stay in for a week. Dr. Gonzalez will meet with the patient again before the surgery to answer any final questions and provide additional instructions.

subjective: Kelly Wood, born February 15th, 1979, reported to have passed two small stones earlier last week and currently has no lower back pain or tenderness. She also reported a few episodes of hematuria (visible blood in urine) for the past six weeks. Her pain, when passing the stones, was severe, she rated it as an eight on the scale of zero to ten. She also acknowledged not drinking the recommended amount of water per day and consuming more Mountain Dew.
objective: Urinalysis showed a trace amount of blood in the urine. Renal ultrasound revealed the right kidney is of normal size and free from obstructions, while the left kidney has a nonobstructing 6mm stone. Mrs. Wood's prescription medication consists solely of Alavert 10mg per day and she has no known drug allergies. The physical exam showed no flank pain and was otherwise normal.
assessment_and_plan: Mrs. Wood was diagnosed with hematuria and chronic urolithiasis. Given the stone was not causing further issues or pain, no surgical intervention was planned. Mrs. Wood was advised to drink approximately half her weight in ounces of water per day and reduce her consumption of sodium, oxalate, and animal proteinrich foods which contribute to kidney stone formation. The doctor also provided a detailed handout for Mrs. Wood to assist in remembering the dietary changes. Her followup appointment is scheduled for next year unless further symptoms like bleeding or pain occur before then.

subjective: Melissa Sanchez, born on 9/23/1962, reported feeling overall better postmitral valve repair surgery done on 8/3/2020. However, she still experiences occasional chest pain and shallow breathing, especially when exerting herself. These symptoms last only a few minutes and occur a couple of times a month. She has been managing her symptoms by slowing down when they occur. She has been taking her medications regularly with assistance from a reminder app. The patient reports initial irritation from Atenolol but has now gotten used to it.
objective: Physical exam shows that Ms. Sanchez's lungs have reduced breath, but auscultation and percussion are clear. Her cardiac rhythm is irregularly irregular, a sign of her atrial fibrillation. Ms. Sanchez does not feel any pain when her belly and feet are touched. Trace peripheral edema on extremities was observed. ECG taken on 12/26/2020 shows controlled atrial fibrillation and a Twave inversion anteriorly. However, there are no significant changes compared to the previous study.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor believes that Ms. Sanchez is recovering well from her mitral valve repair surgery. Her heart valves are functioning well. Her atrial fibrillation is under control with medication. The doctor plans to keep Ms. Sanchez on her current medications Coumadin, Lasix, and Atenolol. The doctor recommends to Ms. Sanchez to keep active and slow down when she experiences symptoms. A followup appointment is recommended in six to nine months, and no immediate return is necessary unless her symptoms worsen.

subjective: The patient, Judy Gomez, discussed the ongoing management of her psoriatic arthritis. She confirmed taking one prednisone tablet per day, occasionally increasing the dosage due to pain in her feet, especially after physical activity. Judy noted that the pain relief from methotrexate was significant. Additionally, she expressed concerns about the interference of methotrexate with her COVID19 vaccination and reported feeling significantly worse when she didn't take the medication during her vaccine week. Judy also reported unexplained bruising and pain in her joints, particularly in her feet, and questioned the cause of these symptoms.
objective: The doctor physically examined the patient's feet and knee joints, observing good range of motion and noting the presence of ridges in her nails, a sign attributed to psoriasis.
assessment_and_plan: The patient's psoriatic arthritis is being managed, with improvements noted with the use of methotrexate. The prednisone dosage has been reduced successfully to a point where cessation of the medication is considered possible. Patient's report of unexplained bruising is likely due to the use of prednisone. The doctor decided to discontinue the use of prednisone, continue with the methotrexate treatment and advised Judy to monitor for any changes in her symptoms, particularly the unexplained bruising. Blood work was also ordered to monitor Judy's condition and response to medication. The patient was advised to return in three months for a followup appointment.

subjective: Patient Diana Scott presented with a new diagnosis of a heart murmur. She has experienced leg pain severe enough to require pain medication and she gets short of breath when walking long distances or trying to drink a whole glass of water at once. She noticed these symptoms intensifying 7080% in the past six months. Patient also experiences intermittent ankle swelling for the past six months, has lost weight gradually over the year, and feels overly tired due to her medication regimen. Diana reported lightheadedness and dizziness for which she takes medication when necessary. The patient has a family history of heart disease and her legs have been severely painful for a month, but she's experienced no chest pain.
objective: The doctor performed a physical examination and found a 4/6 systolic murmur at the upper right sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids. This murmur is possibly a sign of aortic stenosis. She had some outside records indicating diastolic dysfunction suggesting a possible previous echocardiogram. Patient's EKG shows sinus rhythm with frequent pvcs and an anterior septum infarct pattern.
assessment_and_plan: The doctor planned for an echocardiogram to assess cardiac structure and function due to the observed syndromes. Aortic Stenosis is suspected and depending on the severity after the echocardiogram, further ischemic evaluation or possibly a heart monitor may be required. The statin medication could be considered for the bilateral leg pains. The doctor also discussed the possibility of Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR) if the aortic stenosis was severe. Hyperthyroidism to be continued with current medication  levothyroxine. Patient to follow up in threefour weeks after the echocardiogram for discussing results and next steps. The doctor advised the patient to continue taking her present doses of amlodipine or lisinopril as her blood pressure seemed wellcontrolled. The issue of patient's statins needs to be discussed with her primary care practitioner, based on the results of the echocardiogram and her leg pain.
